results.title: Do beta-adrenergic blocking agents increase asthma exacerbation? A network meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials
results.text_hl: The primary results of the NMA remained largely unchanged, except that oral @<m>CHEMICAL_Atenolol</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D001262 @@@atenolol@@@ was associated with a significantly lower incidence of @<m>DISEASE_Asthma</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D001249 @@@asthma@@@ attack [RR = 0.33 (95% CI 0.14-0.74)] than the placebo or control groups (Table 2, eFigure 2 and eTable 6C).

citations.NLM: Huang KY, Tseng PT, Wu YC, Tu YK, Stubbs B, Su KP, Matsuoka YJ, Hsu CW, Lin CH, Chen YW, Lin PY. Do beta-adrenergic blocking agents increase asthma exacerbation? A network meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials Sci Rep. 2021 Jan 11;11(1):452. PMID: 33432057

results.title: Asthma and beta-blockers.
results.text_hl: It was concluded that, in @SPECIES_9606 @@@patients@@@ with @<m>DISEASE_Asthma</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D001249 @@@asthma@@@ who require beta blockade, @<m>CHEMICAL_Atenolol</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D001262 @@@atenolol@@@ is the preferred agent, co-prescribed with a beta2 stimulant.
